Plain-language definition: A standard way to write genetic changes so everyone reads them the same.
Formal/technical definition: Human Genome Variation Society (HGVS) nomenclature system for describing sequence variants at the genomic (g.), coding DNA (c.), non-coding RNA (n.), mitochondrial (m.), RNA (r.) and protein (p.) levels.

Plain-language definition: Variant written as a chromosome coordinate.
Formal/technical definition: HGVS level designator 'g.' for genomic sequences; coordinates referenced to a genome assembly (e.g., GRCh37/GRCh38).
Example/Notes: g.43045729C>T on chr17 (GRCh38).

Plain-language definition: Variant written relative to a transcript’s coding sequence.
Formal/technical definition: HGVS 'c.' designator; positions counted from the A of the ATG start codon as c.1.

Plain-language definition: Variant written as the protein change it causes.
Formal/technical definition: HGVS 'p.' notation using amino acid codes to denote changes (missense, nonsense, frameshift, etc.).
Example/Notes: p.Gly12Asp; p.Trp24Ter; p.Val600Glu.

Plain-language definition: Variant written relative to the mitochondrial genome.
Formal/technical definition: HGVS 'm.' designator for mitochondrial genome positions.

Plain-language definition: A unique rs-number that identifies a variant in dbSNP.
Formal/technical definition: dbSNP Reference SNP cluster ID that aggregates submissions representing the same variant.
Example/Notes: rs429358 in APOE.

Plain-language definition: Stable ID for a ClinVar allele record.
Formal/technical definition: ClinVar allele accession representing a unique submitted allele record (independent of interpretations).

Plain-language definition: ClinVar’s variation record ID that holds clinical assertions.
Formal/technical definition: VCV identifier references ClinVar variation archive entries containing clinical interpretations and evidence.

Plain-language definition: The agreed 'main' transcript to use for clinical reporting.
Formal/technical definition: Matched Annotation from NCBI and EMBL-EBI: MANE Select is a single representative transcript per gene harmonized between RefSeq and Ensembl.
Example/Notes: BRCA1 MANE Select: NM_007294.4 = ENST00000357654.9.

Plain-language definition: Additional clinically relevant transcripts beyond the Select one.
Formal/technical definition: MANE Plus Clinical includes extra transcripts important for clinical reporting for some genes with multiple clinically significant isoforms.
Example/Notes: Genes with multiple clinically used transcripts (e.g., TTN).

Plain-language definition: Official short name for a gene.
Formal/technical definition: HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee assigns unique gene symbols and names to human genes.
Example/Notes: BRCA1, CFTR.

Plain-language definition: Which human genome version coordinates refer to.
Formal/technical definition: Reference genome assembly versions used as positional references (GRCh37/hg19, GRCh38/hg38).

Plain-language definition: Chromosomal location label seen under a microscope.
Formal/technical definition: Giemsa-staining based chromosome region notation such as 17q21.31.
Example/Notes: BRCA1 at 17q21.31.

Plain-language definition: A DNA change that swaps one amino acid for another.
Formal/technical definition: Single nucleotide variant altering a codon such that a different amino acid is encoded.
Example/Notes: c.35G>A → p.Gly12Asp.

Plain-language definition: A DNA change that does not change the amino acid.
Formal/technical definition: Codon change that leaves the encoded amino acid unchanged (often assumed neutral, but can affect splicing/regulation).
Example/Notes: c.354G>A → p.Gly118Gly.

Plain-language definition: A DNA change that creates a stop signal, truncating the protein.
Formal/technical definition: SNV that introduces a premature termination codon (PTC).
Example/Notes: p.Trp24Ter (p.W24*).

Plain-language definition: Insertion/deletion that shifts the reading frame, usually breaking the protein.
Formal/technical definition: Indel not in multiples of three nucleotides causing downstream codon re-interpretation and often PTC/NMD.
Example/Notes: c.100_101del → p.Ser34Valfs*12.

Plain-language definition: Bases added/removed in multiples of three so reading frame stays intact.
Formal/technical definition: Insertion/deletion of nucleotides that preserves codon frame, altering protein length by amino acids rather than shifting frame.
Example/Notes: c.90_92del → p.Lys31del.

Plain-language definition: Change at intron–exon borders that may change RNA splicing.
Formal/technical definition: Variant affecting canonical splice donor (±1/2) or acceptor (±1/2) sites, potentially causing exon skipping or cryptic splice use.

Plain-language definition: Change near splice sites that may alter splicing.
Formal/technical definition: Variant within near-splice intronic/exonic regions that can influence splice efficiency or create new splice sites (commonly ±3–8 intronic or exonic −3/+5).

Plain-language definition: Change that disrupts the start codon, possibly blocking translation initiation.
Formal/technical definition: Variant affecting the canonical ATG initiation codon (c.1) leading to uncertain translation from downstream ATG.
Example/Notes: c.1A>G (p.Met1?).

Plain-language definition: Change that removes the natural stop codon, lengthening the protein.
Formal/technical definition: Variant converting a stop codon into a sense codon, producing protein extension until next stop codon.
Example/Notes: p.*200Glnext*45.

Plain-language definition: A big chunk of DNA is deleted or duplicated.
Formal/technical definition: Structural variant altering copy number of genomic segments, typically >50 bp, often kb–Mb.
Example/Notes: Heterozygous deletion of exon 7.

Plain-language definition: Large DNA change in structure or position of segments.
Formal/technical definition: Genomic alterations >50 bp including deletions, duplications, inversions, translocations, insertions, mobile element insertions, repeat expansions.
Example/Notes: Balanced translocation t(9;22).

Plain-language definition: Insertion of transposable elements like Alu/LINE into DNA.
Formal/technical definition: Insertion events of transposable elements that may disrupt genes or regulation.
Example/Notes: Alu insertion in BRCA2 intron.

Plain-language definition: Short DNA sequences repeated many times; expansions can cause disease.
Formal/technical definition: Microsatellite repeats (1–6 bp) whose expanded lengths beyond thresholds cause disorders.
Example/Notes: HTT CAG expansion in Huntington disease.

Plain-language definition: Disease from too many repeats.
Formal/technical definition: Pathogenic increase in short tandem repeat count above normal range causing disease via gain-of-function, toxic RNA/protein, or loss of expression.
Example/Notes: FMR1 CGG >200 (Fragile X syndrome).

Plain-language definition: How often a variant occurs in a population.
Formal/technical definition: Proportion of chromosomes carrying an allele in a defined population; minor allele frequency (MAF) is the less common allele frequency.

Plain-language definition: How many alternate alleles were observed in a dataset.
Formal/technical definition: Number of alternate allele observations across all samples in a dataset.
Example/Notes: AC = 5 in a dataset of 10,000 chromosomes.

Plain-language definition: Total chromosomes assessed (denominator for AF).
Formal/technical definition: Total number of chromosomes at the locus considered (2N for diploids minus missing genotypes).
Example/Notes: AN = 20000 for 10,000 diploid samples.

Plain-language definition: What fraction of DNA reads carry the variant.
Formal/technical definition: Proportion of sequencing reads supporting the alternate allele; ~50% expected for germline heterozygous, ~100% for homozygous, lower for mosaic/somatic.
Example/Notes: VAF 0.48 suggests heterozygous germline.

Plain-language definition: Whether the two copies of a gene are the same or different.
Formal/technical definition: Homozygous (both alleles same), heterozygous (two different alleles), hemizygous (one copy in sex chromosomes).
Example/Notes: Heterozygous c.35G>A.

Plain-language definition: How a condition is passed through families.
Formal/technical definition: Pattern of transmission including autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, X-linked, mitochondrial, digenic, polygenic/multifactorial.
Example/Notes: Autosomal recessive for cystic fibrosis.

Plain-language definition: How many people with a change actually get the disease.
Formal/technical definition: Probability that individuals with a genotype will manifest the phenotype, often age-dependent.
Example/Notes: BRCA1 carriage: age-dependent penetrance for breast cancer (~45–70% lifetime).

Plain-language definition: How strongly or differently a disease appears in different people with the same variant.
Formal/technical definition: Variation in signs or severity among individuals with the same genotype.
Example/Notes: Neurofibromatosis 1 shows variable expressivity (skin findings to tumors).

Plain-language definition: When having only one working copy of a gene isn't enough.
Formal/technical definition: When loss-of-function (LOF) of one allele causes disease because the remaining allele cannot supply sufficient function.
Example/Notes: Some developmental disorder genes are haploinsufficient.

Plain-language definition: Having an extra copy of a gene causes disease.
Formal/technical definition: Increased dosage due to duplication/triplication leads to phenotype in dosage-sensitive genes.
Example/Notes: Certain gene duplications cause neurodevelopmental disorders.

Plain-language definition: Two different variants on two gene copies cause recessive disease.
Formal/technical definition: Presence of two distinct pathogenic alleles in trans in the same gene leading to disease in recessive conditions.
Example/Notes: CFTR: c.1521_1523delCTT and p.Gly551Asp in trans.

Plain-language definition: A new variant present in the patient but not in parents.
Formal/technical definition: Variant arising in the germline or early embryo; not found in parental DNA testing.
Example/Notes: Trio testing finds variant absent in both parents.

Plain-language definition: Not all cells have the same DNA change in a person.
Formal/technical definition: Presence of two or more genetically distinct cell populations derived from a single zygote; variant allele fraction often <50% depending on tissue and timing.
Example/Notes: Post-zygotic variant with VAF ~10% in blood.

Plain-language definition: A variant common in a group because ancestors carried it.
Formal/technical definition: Allele with elevated frequency in a population due to founder effect and genetic drift.
Example/Notes: BRCA1 c.68_69delAG in Ashkenazi Jews.

Plain-language definition: Plain-language definition
Formal/technical definition: Formal/technical definition
Example/Notes: Example/Notes

Plain-language definition: Strong evidence the variant causes disease.
Formal/technical definition: ACMG/AMP clinical significance category indicating sufficient evidence that the variant is disease-causing.
Example/Notes: ClinVar: Pathogenic annotation for a variant in BRCA1.

Plain-language definition: High chance the variant causes disease.
Formal/technical definition: ACMG/AMP category indicating >90% probability of pathogenicity based on aggregated evidence.
Example/Notes: Often used when multiple supportive lines of evidence exist but not definitive.

Plain-language definition: Not enough evidence to say whether the variant is harmful or not.
Formal/technical definition: ACMG/AMP category assigned when data are insufficient, conflicting, or absent to reach benign/pathogenic.
Example/Notes: Common interim classification for novel variants in new genes.

Plain-language definition: Probably not disease-causing.
Formal/technical definition: ACMG/AMP category indicating strong evidence for benign impact, but not definitive.
Example/Notes: Used when multiple benign criteria are met.

Plain-language definition: Strong evidence the variant is not harmful.
Formal/technical definition: ACMG/AMP clinical significance category supporting non-pathogenic status.
Example/Notes: High-frequency population polymorphisms often classified benign.

Plain-language definition: Standard rules to classify genetic variants clinically.
Formal/technical definition: 2015 joint standards and guidelines with evidence codes (PVS1, PS, PM, PP, BS, BP, BA) to combine evidence into classifications.
Example/Notes: PVS1 for loss-of-function in LOF genes; PM2 for rarity in population databases.

Plain-language definition: Very strong evidence for pathogenicity if variant causes loss of function in a gene where LOF is disease mechanism.
Formal/technical definition: Null variants (nonsense, frameshift, canonical ±1/2 splice site, initiation codon, exon deletion) in genes where LOF is established mechanism. Strength can be moderated by gene-specific rules.
Example/Notes: p.Trp24Ter in a LOF gene with established haploinsufficiency.

Plain-language definition: Strong evidence: the variant causes same amino acid change as a known pathogenic variant but via a different DNA change.
Formal/technical definition: Same protein change as previously established pathogenic variant (different codon/nucleotide change).
Example/Notes: Different nucleotide causing p.Arg117His where p.Arg117His is known pathogenic.

Plain-language definition: Strong evidence from confirmed de novo occurrence.
Formal/technical definition: Variant confirmed de novo (in affected with no family history) with parental relationships verified (e.g., by testing).
Example/Notes: Trio confirming variant absent in both parents for a dominant disease.

Plain-language definition: Strong evidence from functional studies demonstrating a damaging effect.
Formal/technical definition: Well-established in vitro/in vivo functional studies supporting damaging effect on gene/protein.
Example/Notes: Cellular assay showing loss of protein function.

Plain-language definition: Strong evidence if variant is significantly more common in affected individuals vs controls.
Formal/technical definition: Statistically significant enrichment of variant in cases versus controls.
Example/Notes: Observed in multiple unrelated affected patients compared with population controls.

Plain-language definition: Moderate evidence: variant in mutational hotspot or critical domain without benign variation.
Formal/technical definition: Located in well-established functional domain or hotspot essential for protein function.
Example/Notes: Variant in kinase domain hotspot known for activating mutations.

Plain-language definition: Moderate evidence from rarity or absence in population databases.
Formal/technical definition: Absent or extremely rare in controls for a disorder with full penetrance at early age.
Example/Notes: Not observed in gnomAD or below disease-specific threshold.

Plain-language definition: Moderate evidence when variant is observed in trans with pathogenic variant for recessive disorders.
Formal/technical definition: Detection in trans with a known pathogenic variant supports pathogenicity in recessive disease.
Example/Notes: Compound heterozygous configuration with pathogenic allele in trans.

Plain-language definition: Moderate evidence: protein length changes due to in-frame indels or stop-loss.
Formal/technical definition: In-frame indels or stop-loss in non-repeat regions that alter protein length.
Example/Notes: In-frame deletion removing critical residues in functional domain.

Plain-language definition: Moderate evidence for a novel missense at a residue where other missense changes are pathogenic.
Formal/technical definition: Novel missense at residue with known pathogenic missense variant(s).
Example/Notes: Missense at same amino acid position as known pathogenic variant.

Plain-language definition: Supporting evidence from cosegregation with disease in families.
Formal/technical definition: Variant showing segregation with disease in multiple affected relatives.
Example/Notes: Observed in multiple affected relatives consistent with inheritance pattern.

Plain-language definition: Supporting evidence from multiple computational predictors suggesting deleterious effect.
Formal/technical definition: Computational predictions for deleteriousness (conservation, splicing, structural impact) across multiple tools.
Example/Notes: High CADD and deleterious SIFT/PolyPhen predictions for missense.

Plain-language definition: Supporting benign evidence when missense change occurs in gene where only truncating variants cause disease.
Formal/technical definition: Missense substitution in gene where LOF is main mechanism; missense less likely to be pathogenic.
Example/Notes: Missense in a haploinsufficient gene primarily impacted by truncating variants.

Plain-language definition: Strong benign evidence when allele frequency is too high for a rare disease.
Formal/technical definition: Allele frequency greater than expected for disorder prevalence and penetrance supporting benign classification.
Example/Notes: Common variant frequency in gnomAD above disease threshold (BA1/BS1 criteria).

Plain-language definition: Strong benign evidence if variant observed in healthy adults inconsistent with disease.
Formal/technical definition: Observed in unaffected older individuals or in trans with pathogenic allele for a fully penetrant dominant condition.
Example/Notes: Seen in unaffected older adult population samples.

Plain-language definition: Supporting benign evidence when computational tools predict no impact.
Formal/technical definition: Multiple computational tools predict no deleterious effect on gene/protein.
Example/Notes: Benign predictions across SIFT/PolyPhen/CADD below thresholds.

Plain-language definition: Using how common a variant is to evaluate pathogenicity/benignity.
Formal/technical definition: BA1 (stand-alone benign) and BS1 (strong benign) indicate frequency high enough to be inconsistent with rare disease; PM2 indicates absent/rare in controls supporting pathogenic.
Example/Notes: BA1 = too common; PM2 = absent/rare.

Plain-language definition: Public archive of clinical variant interpretations and supporting evidence.
Formal/technical definition: NIH database aggregating submissions on variants, clinical significance annotations, and supporting evidence with review status.
Example/Notes: Entries labelled Pathogenic/BENIGN/VUS with submitter evidence and review stars.

Plain-language definition: Large population reference giving variant frequencies and constraint metrics.
Formal/technical definition: Genome Aggregation Database of exomes/genomes providing allele frequencies across populations and gene constraint metrics (LOEUF, pLI legacy).
Example/Notes: AF, AC, AN, LOEUF values per gene.

Plain-language definition: Curated catalog linking genes to human phenotypes.
Formal/technical definition: Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man: authoritative compendium of human genes and genetic phenotypes with MIM numbers and clinical summaries.
Example/Notes: OMIM entries for gene–disease relationships, e.g., BRCA1 MIM.

Plain-language definition: Clinical, peer-reviewed summaries on genetic conditions and counseling.
Formal/technical definition: Expert-authored chapters covering diagnosis, management, genetics, and counseling for inherited disorders.
Example/Notes: GeneReviews chapters often used for counseling and management guidance.

Plain-language definition: Public catalog of small variants with rsIDs.
Formal/technical definition: NCBI resource for single nucleotide polymorphisms and small indels; rsIDs used widely in literature and databases.
Example/Notes: rsIDs such as rs429358.

Plain-language definition: Public database of structural variants/CNVs.
Formal/technical definition: NCBI database for large genomic variants and structural variant records.
Example/Notes: dbVar accessions for large deletions/duplications.

Plain-language definition: Clinical database linking CNVs/SVs to phenotypes for rare disorders.
Formal/technical definition: Database of Chromosomal Imbalance and Phenotype in Humans using Ensembl resources.
Example/Notes: Used to match patient CNVs to reported cases with phenotype.

Plain-language definition: Locus-specific variant databases curated per gene/group.
Formal/technical definition: Leiden Open Variation Database hosts gene-centric variant submissions with literature curation.
Example/Notes: Gene-specific curated variant lists for some clinical labs or research groups.

Plain-language definition: Human Gene Mutation Database: literature-curated disease-causing variants (subscription).
Formal/technical definition: Commercially curated resource of published disease-associated variants with literature references.
Example/Notes: Used in research and clinical annotation where licensed.

Plain-language definition: Tool that annotates variant consequences across transcripts and databases.
Formal/technical definition: Ensembl Variant Effect Predictor annotates consequences, transcript impacts, population frequency annotations, and in silico predictions.
Example/Notes: Outputs predicted consequence (missense, stop_gained) per transcript.

Plain-language definition: Command-line tool to annotate variants with gene, population and functional data.
Formal/technical definition: Functional annotation tool that adds gene-based, region-based and filter-based annotations from multiple databases.
Example/Notes: Used to annotate VCFs with gnomAD, ClinVar, dbSNP, etc.

Plain-language definition: Program that predicts variant impact on genes/transcripts.
Formal/technical definition: Annotation tool predicting effect (high/moderate/low) and consequence types on various transcripts.
Example/Notes: Classifies variant impact categories for VCF files.

Plain-language definition: Tool that predicts whether an amino acid change affects protein function.
Formal/technical definition: Sequence-homology based predictor scoring missense variants; scores <0.05 often considered deleterious.
Example/Notes: SIFT score 0.02 → predicted damaging.

Plain-language definition: Tool that predicts if a missense change is likely damaging.
Formal/technical definition: Uses sequence/structure features to categorize missense as benign/possibly/probably damaging.
Example/Notes: PolyPhen-2: probably damaging for some missense.

Plain-language definition: Combined score reflecting variant deleteriousness across annotations.
Formal/technical definition: Combined Annotation Dependent Depletion (CADD) integrates multiple annotations into a PHRED-like score; higher indicates greater predicted deleteriousness.
Example/Notes: CADD PHRED ≥20 often considered potentially damaging.

Plain-language definition: Ensemble score for missense pathogenicity from many tools.
Formal/technical definition: Meta-predictor combining multiple missense prediction tools producing score 0–1 (higher = more likely pathogenic).
Example/Notes: REVEL score 0.7 suggests likely deleterious for missense.

Plain-language definition: Deep learning model predicting splice impact of variants.
Formal/technical definition: Estimates probability and position for splice gain/loss due to variants; Δ score closer to 1 indicates stronger predicted splice effect.
Example/Notes: SpliceAI Δ ≥0.5 often considered significant for splicing impact.

Plain-language definition: Legacy measure of a gene’s intolerance to loss-of-function variants.
Formal/technical definition: Probability of being loss-of-function intolerant (ExAC legacy); pLI ≥0.9 indicates LOF intolerance.
Example/Notes: Used historically to prioritize LOF variants in constrained genes.

Plain-language definition: Updated gnomAD metric measuring LOF intolerance.
Formal/technical definition: Loss-of-function observed/expected upper bound fraction (LOEUF); lower values indicate stronger constraint.
Example/Notes: LOEUF 0.2 suggests high intolerance to LOF.

Plain-language definition: Z-score showing intolerance of a gene to missense variation.
Formal/technical definition: Higher positive Z-score indicates stronger depletion of missense variation relative to expectation.
Example/Notes: High Z-score suggests missense-constrained gene for which missense variants may be more significant.

Plain-language definition: Group that curates gene–disease validity, dosage sensitivity, and provides curation resources.
Formal/technical definition: Clinical Genome Resource developing expert curation and resources for variant and gene-disease interpretation.
Example/Notes: ClinGen gene–disease validity categories, dosage sensitivity maps.

Plain-language definition: How strongly a gene is linked to a disease.
Formal/technical definition: ClinGen framework classifies gene–disease associations as Definitive, Strong, Moderate, Limited, Disputed, Refuted, or No Known Disease Relationship.
Example/Notes: Used to trust variant interpretation in given gene for clinical use.

Plain-language definition: Curation of genes for haploinsufficiency and triplosensitivity.
Formal/technical definition: ClinGen assigns haploinsufficiency (HI) and triplosensitivity (TS) scores (0–3) indicating strength of evidence for dosage sensitivity.
Example/Notes: HI score 3 = sufficient evidence of haploinsufficiency causing disease.

Plain-language definition: Plain-language definition
Formal/technical definition: Formal/technical definition
Example/Notes: Example/Notes

Plain-language definition: Sequencing just the protein-coding parts of genes.
Formal/technical definition: High-throughput sequencing of captured exonic regions to detect SNVs/indels in coding sequence and splice junctions.
Example/Notes: Typical mean depth 80–150× for exomes; may miss CNVs and non-coding variants.

Plain-language definition: Sequencing nearly the entire genome, coding and noncoding.
Formal/technical definition: Shotgun sequencing of genomic DNA providing base-level coverage of coding and noncoding regions and improved structural variant detection vs WES.
Example/Notes: Better for SVs and non-coding variants; larger data volume/cost.

Plain-language definition: Sequencing a selected set of genes related to a phenotype.
Formal/technical definition: NGS limited to curated gene list for a given disease domain (e.g., cardiomyopathy panel).
Example/Notes: Faster and cheaper than WES for focused questions; limited scope.

Plain-language definition: High-accuracy method to read a short DNA segment.
Formal/technical definition: Dideoxy chain-termination sequencing (gold-standard) used to confirm NGS variants and to sequence small regions.
Example/Notes: Used frequently to validate NGS calls or test specific variants.

Plain-language definition: Method to detect exon-level deletions/duplications.
Formal/technical definition: Multiplex Ligation-dependent Probe Amplification measures relative copy number of exons for specific genes.
Example/Notes: Common for detecting single-exon deletions/duplications (e.g., DMD, SMN1).

Plain-language definition: Quantifies DNA to infer copy number or expression.
Formal/technical definition: Quantitative PCR used for CNV confirmation or gene expression assays.
Example/Notes: Used to validate CNV calls from arrays or NGS.

Plain-language definition: How many sequencing reads cover a base.
Formal/technical definition: Number of reads overlapping a genomic locus; higher depth generally increases confidence in variant calls.
Example/Notes: Exome may aim for mean 100×; clinical pipelines require coverage thresholds per region.

Plain-language definition: Confidence score in the genotype call.
Formal/technical definition: Phred-scaled probability that the genotype is incorrect; higher GQ indicates higher confidence.
Example/Notes: GQ ≥20 often considered acceptable for germline.

Plain-language definition: Confidence score that a variant exists at the site.
Formal/technical definition: Phred-scaled confidence in the variant call itself.
Example/Notes: Used in VCF fields for variant filtering.

Plain-language definition: Smallest variant level a test can reliably detect.
Formal/technical definition: Lowest VAF or smallest copy change detectable with specified sensitivity/specificity; important for somatic assays.
Example/Notes: Somatic panels LoD often ~2–5% VAF.

Plain-language definition: Parts of the genome a test is validated to detect and report.
Formal/technical definition: Validated genomic regions where analytical performance meets required thresholds and results can be reported clinically.
Example/Notes: Exome reportable range may exclude poorly covered exons.

Plain-language definition: Whether two variants are on the same chromosome (cis) or opposite ones (trans).
Formal/technical definition: Determination of cis vs trans configuration via parental testing, read-backed phasing, or long reads; relevant for compound het interpretation.
Example/Notes: Compound het requires trans for recessive disease.

Plain-language definition: Cis means same chromosome; trans means opposite chromosomes.
Formal/technical definition: Relative arrangement of alleles/haplotypes affecting interpretation (cis may not produce recessive disease if both variants on same allele).
Example/Notes: Two variants in cis on same chromosome vs trans on opposite chromosomes.

Plain-language definition: Checking if a variant tracks with disease in a family.
Formal/technical definition: Statistical and qualitative co-segregation analysis to support pathogenicity (PP1/BS4 criteria).
Example/Notes: Strong segregation supports pathogenicity; lack of segregation supports benignity.

Plain-language definition: Cell process that removes mRNAs with early stops to prevent truncated protein.
Formal/technical definition: Eukaryotic surveillance pathway degrading transcripts with premature termination codons typically >50–55 nt upstream of last exon–exon junction.
Example/Notes: NMD may influence whether PTC causes LOF vs escape leads to truncated protein with gain/loss effects.

Plain-language definition: Strength of evidence a gene causes a disease.
Formal/technical definition: ClinGen framework with categories: Definitive, Strong, Moderate, Limited, Disputed, Refuted, No Known Disease Relationship.
Example/Notes: Used for confidence in interpreting variants in the gene for a given phenotype.

Plain-language definition: Whether a genetic result can guide prevention, treatment, or management.
Formal/technical definition: ClinGen and other resources assess clinical actionability including severity, likelihood, and effectiveness of interventions.
Example/Notes: ACMG secondary findings list elements are considered actionable.

Plain-language definition: Genes/variants recommended for opportunistic reporting when found incidentally because they are actionable.
Formal/technical definition: ACMG periodically publishes list of genes where pathogenic variants should be reported if identified in clinical sequencing regardless of testing indication.
Example/Notes: ACMG SF v3.1 (example update cycle).

Plain-language definition: How much review/support backs a ClinVar assertion.
Formal/technical definition: ClinVar review status stars indicate review level: one submitter, multiple submitters, expert panel, practice guideline, etc.
Example/Notes: ★ (single submitter) to ★★★★ (practice guideline/expert panel).

Plain-language definition: A maternal blood test that screens fetal chromosomes using fetal DNA in the mother's blood.
Formal/technical definition: Analysis of cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) in maternal plasma to screen for common aneuploidies (trisomy 21/18/13) and some microdeletions; screening not diagnostic.
Example/Notes: High sensitivity/specificity for T21; positive results should be confirmed with diagnostic testing (CVS/amniocentesis).

Plain-language definition: Sampling placenta tissue to test fetal DNA earlier in pregnancy.
Formal/technical definition: Invasive prenatal diagnostic procedure to obtain chorionic villi for cytogenetic or molecular testing, typically ~10–13+6 weeks.
Example/Notes: Provides diagnostic result for chromosomal and many single-gene conditions.

Plain-language definition: Sampling amniotic fluid around the fetus to test fetal DNA.
Formal/technical definition: Invasive diagnostic procedure, usually performed after 15 weeks, to obtain amniotic fluid for karyotype, microarray or molecular tests.
Example/Notes: Gold-standard diagnostic testing for aneuploidy and many genetic diagnoses.

Plain-language definition: Ultrasound + blood markers to estimate risk for Down syndrome in early pregnancy.
Formal/technical definition: NT ultrasound combined with maternal serum markers (PAPP-A and free β-hCG) at 11–13+6 weeks to provide a risk estimate for trisomy 21 and 18; positive screens prompt counseling and further testing.
Example/Notes: Screening, not diagnostic.

Plain-language definition: Second-trimester blood test measuring four proteins to estimate risk of certain fetal conditions.
Formal/technical definition: Measures AFP, hCG, estriol (uE3), and inhibin-A in second trimester to assess risk for neural tube defects and aneuploidies; less specific than NIPT for common aneuploidies.
Example/Notes: Screen result should be followed by counseling/testing if high risk.

Plain-language definition: Portion of fetal DNA in the mother’s blood sample used for NIPT.
Formal/technical definition: Percentage of cell-free DNA in maternal plasma derived from placenta (fetal) — low fetal fraction reduces NIPT accuracy; thresholds depend on platform.
Example/Notes: Typical minimum ~4% fetal fraction required for valid NIPT result on many platforms.

Plain-language definition: Ultrasound measure of fluid at the back of a fetus’s neck; higher values can indicate chromosome problems.
Formal/technical definition: First-trimester ultrasound measurement used in risk assessment for aneuploidy and structural defects.
Example/Notes: Increased NT may prompt further genetic testing and fetal echocardiography.

Plain-language definition: Guidelines to classify tumor variants for clinical actionability.
Formal/technical definition: AMP/ASCO/CAP joint consensus tiering for somatic variants classifying therapeutic/diagnostic/prognostic significance (Tier I–IV).
Example/Notes: Tier I variants have strong clinical significance (e.g., EGFR L858R in lung cancer).

Plain-language definition: How many mutations are present per megabase in tumor DNA.
Formal/technical definition: Number of somatic mutations per megabase used as a biomarker for immunotherapy response; thresholds vary by assay and tumor type.
Example/Notes: High TMB may predict response to checkpoint inhibitors in some cancers.

Plain-language definition: Many errors in repetitive DNA due to mismatch repair defects.
Formal/technical definition: MSI-High status indicates deficiency in mismatch repair (MMR) and can indicate Lynch syndrome or predict immunotherapy response.
Example/Notes: Detected by PCR or NGS; MSI-High tumors may be Lynch syndrome–associated.

Plain-language definition: Fraction of tumor DNA supporting the variant.
Formal/technical definition: Proportion of reads supporting variant in tumor sample; influenced by tumor purity, clonality, ploidy.
Example/Notes: VAF 0.12 could reflect a subclonal mutation or low tumor purity.

Plain-language definition: EGFR mutations can predict response to certain lung cancer drugs.
Formal/technical definition: Epidermal growth factor receptor activating mutations (e.g., exon 19 deletions, p.L858R) are actionable targets for EGFR TKIs in NSCLC.
Example/Notes: EGFR exon 19del; p.L858R are common actionable variants.

Plain-language definition: ALK gene fusions can respond to ALK inhibitors.
Formal/technical definition: Anaplastic lymphoma kinase fusions (e.g., EML4-ALK) in NSCLC confer sensitivity to ALK-targeted therapies.
Example/Notes: EML4-ALK fusion.

Plain-language definition: BRAF V600E mutation is targetable in melanoma and other cancers.
Formal/technical definition: BRAF p.Val600Glu activating mutation targeted by BRAF/MEK inhibitor therapy in melanoma and other tumor types.
Example/Notes: p.Val600Glu (V600E).

Plain-language definition: KRAS mutations affect prognosis and therapy choices in several cancers.
Formal/technical definition: Activating KRAS mutations (e.g., G12C) are important for targeted therapy decisions and may confer resistance to some targeted agents.
Example/Notes: p.Gly12Cys (G12C).

Plain-language definition: PD-L1 expression helps decide immunotherapy use in certain cancers.
Formal/technical definition: Protein expression of PD-L1 by IHC used as companion diagnostic for checkpoint inhibitors in several tumor types.
Example/Notes: PD-L1 TPS ≥50% in some NSCLC contexts guides therapy.

Plain-language definition: NCBI curated sequences for genes and transcripts.
Formal/technical definition: Reference Sequence database with NM_/NR_ transcript and NP_ protein accessions used in clinical reporting.

Plain-language definition: Genome annotation resource with ENSG/ENST IDs.
Formal/technical definition: EMBL-EBI genome annotation platform providing gene, transcript, and variant annotation.

Plain-language definition: Database- or community-selected main transcript for a gene.
Formal/technical definition: Transcript selected as representative by annotation pipelines or community standards; MANE Select harmonizes between RefSeq and Ensembl.
Example/Notes: MANE Select identifies canonical clinical transcript for reporting.

Plain-language definition: Standard vocabulary for describing patient features.
Formal/technical definition: Human Phenotype Ontology provides coded phenotype terms (HP: numbers) for clinical annotation and computational matching.
Example/Notes: HP:0001250 (Seizure).

Plain-language definition: Portal for rare diseases and orphan drugs and their gene relationships.
Formal/technical definition: Structured resource on rare diseases, prevalence, and gene associations for clinical and research use.
Example/Notes: Used for rare disease annotation and information.

Plain-language definition: Database linking CNVs and genomic disorders to phenotype.
Formal/technical definition: Database of chromosomal imbalance and phenotype in humans using Ensembl resources to aid interpretation of rare CNVs.
Example/Notes: Used for phenotype-driven CNV interpretation.

Plain-language definition: Phrases to include in chatbot responses noting limits of the tool.
Formal/technical definition: Examples: 'This information is educational only and not a substitute for professional medical advice. For diagnosis, please consult a certified genetic counselor or clinical geneticist.'
Example/Notes: Chatbot must include limits, referral suggestions, and escalation prompts for urgent or high-stakes queries.
